questions.question: While evaluating a 3-year-old with short stature, height is measured at 90cm and the lower segment is 45 cm. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia Explanation: In the given scenario, the upper segment: lower segment ratio of the child is 1:1 signifying upper segment short stature which is seen in spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia. The normal US: LS ratio for a 3-year-old child is 1.3: 1. Here the height of the child is 90cm with LS = 45cm. Hence the US = 45cm. US: LS = 1:1. This means that the upper segment is shorter than normal. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia causes short-trunk dwarfism involving the vertebrae and proximal epiphyseal centres. The distal epiphyses are spared in this condition. Proportionate Short Stature Conditions Causing Short Stature with US > LS Conditions Causing Short Stature with US < LS Growth hormone deficiency Genetic syndromes: Noonan syndrome, Prader-Willi syndrome, 3M syndrome Environmental pollutants: Lead, calcium, hexachlorobenzene, polychlorinated biphenyl Family history Achondroplasia (Option A) Congenital hypothyroidism (Option B) Turner syndrome Diastrophic dysplasia Rickets (Option C) Spondyliepiphyseal dysplasia (Option D) Morquio syndrome Reference: O.P. Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page 34, 506 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556031/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563282

questions.question: At which of the following ages does maximum brain growth occur?
questions.explanation: of the first year, the brain reaches about 60% of its adult size. This period is critical for neurodevelopment, with significant increases in brain volume and neural connections. Incorrect options: Option B - 2 years : Brain growth continues, but the rate slows down after the first year. By 2 years of age, the brain is approximately 75% of its adult size, but the most intense phase of growth has already occurred. Option C - 3 years : By 3 years, the brain is about 80-85% of its adult size. Growth is still significant, but it is not as rapid as during the first year. Option D - 4 years : The brain's growth rate further decreases, reaching around 90% of its adult size by this age. Most brain development in terms of structure is completed, but functional maturation continues.

questions.question: A 10 year old child presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infection. Physical examination shows low height for age and Z line score is <-2SD. The parents also have a history of incorrect feeding method. What is the appropriate term for the above mentioned condition?
questions.explanation: as low height-for-age. This condition is a result of long-term nutritional deprivation, often exacerbated by recurrent infections. A Z-score of less than -2 standard deviations (SD) below the median of the World Health Organization's child growth standards is indicative of stunting. The history of incorrect feeding method provided by the parents further supports this diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Wasting: Wasting, or acute malnutrition, is defined as low weight-for-height. It's a sign of recent and severe weight loss, which does not seem to be the case with the child described in the question. Option C - Malnutrition: While the child is indeed malnourished, this term is broad and doesn't specify the type of malnutrition. In this case, the child's low height-for-age and Z-score of <-2SD indicate stunting, a specific form of malnutrition. Option D - Kwashiorkor: Kwashiorkor is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by edema (swelling), discolored hair, and dermatosis. It's typically caused by a diet high in carbohydrates but deficient in protein. The question does not provide any information suggesting the child has these symptoms.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 2.8 kg?

options.A: Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year
options.B: Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
options.C: Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
options.D: Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year Explanation: The best indicator of adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 cm in the first year. Normal length at birth: 50cm. In the first year, there is an increase of 25cm , so at 1 year the height is 75cm. In the second year there is an increase of 10-15cm, so at 2 years the height is 85-90cm. There is a steady increase of 6cm/year till 12 years. Height doubles by 4 years Height triples by 12 years Half of adult height in a normal child (80-85cm) is achieved by 2 years (18-24 months). Age Length At birth 50cm By 3 months 60cm By 9 months 70cm By 1 year 75cm At 2 years 90cm At 4-4.5 years 100cm Weech's formula to estimate the expected weight and height of children using age as a variable. For <1 year : x + 9 ÷ 2 ( Where x is age in months ) For 1-6 years : 2x + 8 ( Where x is age in years ) For 7-12 years : 7x - 5 ÷ 2 ( Where x is age in years ) Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year (Option B): In the first few months, weight gain typically varies from 20-40 grams per day, and after 4 months, it increases to approximately 400 grams per month, with doubling at 5 months and tripling by 1 year. Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age (Option C): The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 9 and 18 months, not by 6 months, making it an unreliable indicator for growth. Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile (Option D): Percentiles are used to compare an infant’s growth measurements with a reference population. However, being under the 75th percentile for weight and under the 25th percentile for height does not guarantee adequate growth. Reference: O.P. Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 12 https://www.pedgen.org.in/growth.php https://journals.lww.com/njcp/fulltext/2020/23090/comparison_of_age_based_weight_estimation_with.8.aspx

questions.question: A 6-year-old child is brought for evaluation of short stature. His height is comparable with his parent’s height and his bone age corresponds to his chronological age. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Familial short stature The clinical presentation indicates familial short stature, which is characterized by height below the 3rd percentile for age and sex but is normal according to the child's genetic potential , as determined by parental heights. Key features supporting this diagnosis include bone age matching chronological age and height being consistent with parental heights, suggesting genetic rather than pathological short stature . Characteristics of Familial Short Stature: Child's height is <3rd percentile of expected according to age & sex, but is normal as per his target height Child has normal puberty Family history of short stature Bone age = chronological age Constitutional delay (Option B): In constitutional growth delay, the child presents with delayed bone age and delayed puberty, unlike this case where bone age matches chronological age. Most of these children tend to eventually grow to approximately the same height as their parents. Undernutrition (Option C): Undernutrition shows evidence of poor weight gain and delayed bone age, which are absent in this case. Nutritional deficiency would affect both growth and skeletal maturation, leading to discrepancy between bone age and chronological age. Growth hormone deficiency (Option D): Growth hormone deficiency, also known as dwarfism or pituitary dwarfism, typically presents with severe growth failure, delayed bone age, and height that is significantly below parental heights. Reference: Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 18-21

questions.question: Gonadal growth corresponds with _____.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Skeletal system Gonadal growth corresponds with skeletal growth , particularly during puberty Estrogen in females and testosterone in males play a significant role in developing secondary sexual characteristics and contribute to the growth and maturation of the skeleton This hormonal influence leads to changes in bone structure and overall height Brain (Option A) growth follows a different pattern, with rapid growth occurring primarily in early childhood and reaching almost adult size by age 6 years. This pattern differs significantly from gonadal development. Lymphoid growth (Option C) follows a unique pattern with peak development occurring before puberty and then involuting, unlike gonadal growth which accelerates during puberty. Lymphoid tissue reaches 200% of adult size during childhood. Dental growth (Option D) follows its own distinct timeline with two separate periods of development - primary and permanent dentition. This pattern does not correspond with gonadal development patterns. Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics 10th Edition, Page 6-7

questions.question: Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: alternative method for the procedure shown is arm span . Ideally, height is measured using an infantometer in children <2 years of age, and a stadiometer is used in children >2 years of age. In conditions such as scoliosis where a stadiometer cannot be used, alternatives such as arm span and upper segment to lower segment (US:LS) ratio are some of the reliable alternatives. Arm span: Measured on arms outstretched at 90 degrees to the body from the tip of the middle finger of one hand to the tip of the middle finger of the other hand. Arm span is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth, equals height at 11 years, and after that is slightly (usually, <1 cm) greater than height. Head circumference (Option A) used to monitor the growth of the brain and skull in children up to 2 years of age. It is measured along the supraorbital ridge in the front and the occipital prominence at the back using a flexible tape. While it reflects brain growth, it does not provide an accurate estimation of height, making it unsuitable for this purpose. Crown-rump length (Option C) is a prenatal measurement used during early pregnancy to assess fetal growth and estimate gestational age, typically from 6-8 weeks of gestation . This measurement is specific to fetuses and cannot be applied to children for height estimation. Knee height (Option D) is used to

questions.question: Which is the first primary tooth to erupt?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lower central incisor The first primary tooth to erupt is the lower central incisor . Primary Dentition Time of eruption Lower central incisor 6 months Upper central incisor (Option A) 7 months Upper lateral incisor 8 months Lower lateral incisor 9 months 1st Molar 1 year Canine (Option C & D) 1.5 years 2nd Molar 2 years Reference: Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th Edition, Page: 11.

questions.question: A child is brought to the paediatrician with short stature. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are low. Which among the following could be the abnormality here?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - GH receptor anomaly The raised levels of growth hormone and low levels of IGF-1 suggest growth hormone insensitivity which is due to GH receptor anomaly. GH stimulates the liver to produce insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), which in turn promotes the growth of bones and tissues. If there is a GH-receptor anomaly in the liver, leads to GH insensitivity. Hene, IGF-1 is not sufficiently produced lowering its concentration in the body. Growth Hormone Receptor anomalies: Laron syndrome: Mutation of the GH receptor leading to growth hormone insensitivity. The GH receptor has an extracellular, transmembrane, and intracellular domain. Mutation of the extracellular domain Affects the binding of the hormone GH-binding protein activity is low Mutation of the transmembrane domain: Affects the anchoring of the receptor to the plasma membrane Normal or high GH-binding protein Mutation of the intracellular domain: Interferes with JAK/STAT signalling GH deficiency (Option A) : If the child had GH deficiency, both GH and IGF-1 levels would typically be low. GHRH deficiency (Option B) : Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) deficiency would typically lead to low GH secretion because GHRH stimulates the release of GH. IGF-1 deficiency (Option D) : Low IGF-1 levels can cause short stature, but the presence of high GH levels suggests that the issue lies not in the production of IGF-1 but in the action of GH itself. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page: 2883, 2884.

questions.question: A 16-month-old boy weighs 8 kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-age) is provided below. What is the most appropriate advice for this child?

options.C: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation centre
options.D: Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother how to feed

questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother how to feed The child's weight for age falls between -2 SD and -3 SD on the growth chart (Moderately underweight). This child's weight is below the average range for his age, indicating some degree of malnutrition. However, it is not severe enough to warrant immediate referral to a nutrition rehabilitation center. Instead, the focus should be on educating the mother or caregiver on proper feeding practices and providing guidance on improving the child's nutritional intake. This may involve promoting a balanced diet, ensuring adequate calorie and nutrient intake, and addressing any feeding difficulties or challenges. WHO Growth Charts Designed specifically to track the growth and development of children under 5 years of age globally. Growth charts are derived from the Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS) carried out by the WHO. This study was a community-based, multi-country initiative that took place in Brazil, Ghana, India, Norway, Oman, and the United States. Features: Provide accurate references for weight, length, and head circumference, reflecting normal growth patterns in children. Percentile Curves : The growth chart displays curves representing percentiles (3rd, 15th, 50th, 85th, and 97th). 3rd Percentile: Lower end of normal growth. 50th Percentile: Median or average growth. 97th Percentile: Higher end of normal growth.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child is brought to the OPD for a regular check-up. His growth chart shows a BMI between the 85th and 95th percentile . Which of the following categories would you place him in?
questions.explanation: the result is plotted on a growth chart to determine the child’s BMI percentile. BMI percentiles in children are classified as follows: Underweight: Less than 5th percentile Healthy weight: 5th percentile to less than 85th percentile Overweight: 85th percentile to less than 95th percentile Obese: Equal to or greater than 95th percentile In this case, the child’s BMI falls between 85th and 95th percentile, which places him in the overweight category. This means that the child’s weight is higher than what is considered healthy for his age, sex, and height. Incorrect Options: Options A, B and D: The BMI in the given clinical scenario does not fit into any of these categories. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A mother expresses concern about her child's unwillingness to eat properly . Her 15-month-old son's length falls 2 standard deviations below the median for his age . What is the most probable medical condition ?
questions.explanation: deviations below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. This indicates that the child has not grown adequately in height and is considered short for age. In this case, the child’s length-for-age is ≤ -2 SD below the median, which indicates moderate stunting. The reluctance to take feeds appropriately may be one reason for the child’s stunted growth. Poor nutrition, frequent infections, and inadequate stimulation can also contribute to stunting. Stunting is associated with impaired cognitive development, poor school performance, and reduced economic productivity in adulthood Incorrect Options: Option A - Acute malnutrition: Acute malnutrition refers to a recent and severe deficiency of energy, protein, and other nutrients that can lead to wasting and/or edema. The child in this scenario is not showing signs of acute malnutrition. Option B - Severe wasting: Severe wasting is defined as a weight-for-height greater than three standard deviations below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. The child’s weight is not provided in the scenario. Option C - Moderately underweight: Moderately underweight is defined as a weight-for-age greater than two standard deviations below the WHO Child Growth Standards median. The child’s weight is not provided in the scenario.

questions.question: How many primary teeth does a 3-year-old child have?
questions.explanation: teeth begin to shed between the ages of 6 and 7, and permanent teeth appear. By age 21, the average person develops 32 teeth, 16 on the upper jaw and 16 on the lower jaw. Primary Dentition (milk/temporary teeth) Secondary Dentition (permanent teeth) Begin at 6 months 6 years 1 tooth to erupt Lower central incisor 1 st molar Last tooth Second molar 3 rd molar (or) wisdom tooth Completes at 2.5-3 years 12 years except for the 3rd molar (18-25 years) Total no. of teeth 20 28-32 Teeth in each quadrant (ICPM) I C P M I C P M 2 1 0 2 2 1 2 3 Incorrect Options Options B, C, and D can be ruled out based on the above explanation. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure preductal oxygen saturation in an infant born 3 minutes ago?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Right upper limb Explanation: Preductal Saturation: Refers to the oxygen saturation before blood passes through the ductus arteriosus . The right upper limb (right hand) receives blood directly from the aorta before the ductus arteriosus , hence it reflects preductal oxygenation . In contrast, the lower limbs and left upper limb may receive blood that is postductal , especially if the ductus is still patent. Clinical Relevance: Preductal SpO I is important during the first minutes after birth to assess the baby's transition from fetal to neonatal circulation. Target preductal SpO I increases gradually over the first 10 minutes of life: ~60–65% at 1 min ~85–95% by 10 min Left upper limb (Option A): This limb may receive postductal blood due to the anatomical position of the ductus arteriosus and is unreliable for preductal measurement. Left lower limb (Option B): Postductal, as it receives blood distal to the ductus arteriosus. Right lower limb (Option D): Also postductal; not appropriate for assessing preductal oxygenation. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2879243/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4281291/
